titleStmt.title: Umm al Qet Harran
SHAWI Corpus
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 33574

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.

spanGrp.span: When we were young, and when the world would start to become damp, meaning when it would start to rain, we would go...
We used to gather, all the boys and girls, and all the friends—everyone would gather.
We would go to someone's house when the rain would start to fall.
We would come to a house with a plate in our hands, holding it, and we would go to a house and say:
"Mother of the rain, rain upon us!"
"Give me a husband with hair."
"My husband, Ḥassān, is bald."
"It has been two years, and he has not planted (harvested)."
"The barley grew as tall as the door."
"And the wheat was abundant, beyond counting."
"That who gives me (sustenance) in a large sack."
"I wish that God makes her son a brave knight."
"That who gives me a small amount, like a handful of the hand."
"I wish that God buries her in the earth."
"That who gives me a bowlful."
"I wish that God makes her son healthy (able to walk)."
So words like these.
To make the homeowner (compelled) to give us wheat.
So then the homeowner fills the bowl with wheat.
"And with this, we gather the wheat, while one of my friends' mothers watches us."
She says: "I will cook it for you." So, she cooks it for us, boiling it, and then we eat it.
And sometimes we scatter it in the fields, just like that, in the open. We go to the fields and sprinkle it on the land.
This is for the rain, we would say. When the rain would fall when we were little, not now.
